title: OpenAI scraps controversial plan to become for-profit after mounting pressure
summary:
On Monday, ChatGPT-maker OpenAI announced it will remain under the control of its founding nonprofit board, scrapping its controversial plan to split off its commercial operations as a for-profit company after mounting pressure from critics.

In an official OpenAI blog post announcing the latest restructuring decision, CEO Sam Altman wrote: "We made the decision for the nonprofit to stay in control after hearing from civic leaders and having discussions with the offices of the Attorneys General of California and Delaware."

The move represents a significant shift in OpenAI's proposed restructuring. While the most recent previous version of the company's plan (which we covered in December) would have established OpenAI as a Public Benefit Corporation with the nonprofit merely holding shares and having limited influence, the revised approach keeps the nonprofit firmly in control of operations.

## OpenAI scraps controversial plan to become for-profit after mounting pressure  

OpenAI has reversed its plan to transition into a for-profit entity, opting instead to remain under the control of its founding nonprofit board. The decision follows criticism and discussions with civic leaders and state attorneys general, as confirmed by CEO Sam Altman in a company blog post. This marks a significant shift from OpenAI’s earlier proposal to restructure as a Public Benefit Corporation, which would have diminished the nonprofit’s influence over operations.  

### Why It Matters  

This reversal underscores OpenAI’s commitment to balancing commercial growth with its original mission-driven ethos. The decision reflects growing scrutiny over AI governance and the ethical responsibilities of leading AI developers. By retaining nonprofit oversight, OpenAI aims to prioritize long-term societal impact over unchecked profit motives—a move that could set a precedent for other AI firms navigating similar tensions.
